3. The chief enjoyment came from the people they were with. Over and over
again, this was cited as the factor most enjoyed. Several school teachers who par¬
ticipated in one group reported they decided to stay in the community rather than
accept offers of employment elshwere, because they enjoyed the friendship of the
people brought together through their ’’Ways of Mankind” group.
4. The participants rediscovered, in many cases, radio as a valuable way of
spending leisure time.
5. The stimulus to think. Many people reported they had "gotten out of the
habit” of thinking or talking about serious matters. They found the intellectual
exercise enjoyable. One woman said;
"Before this experiment started I used to talk to my neighbor over
the fence on my left about her flower garden. I used to talk with
my neighbor on the right over the fence about our children's diets
and the condition of their "b.m.’s”J Now at last I have something
I really want to talk about.”
6. a growing appreciation of the people of other cultures. One man reported
he had never before "understood anything about the people of other societies." He
had thought them "different" and therefore, "odd";
CONCLUSIONS
These appear to be the main experiences gained from the "Ways of Mankind"
Exp riment.
1. Radio and newspaper can work effectively together to stimulate the organi¬
zation of discussion groups and to nurture those which come into existence. The
long-cherished dream of integrating mass media and discussion groups is practical.
2. Natural friendship circles appear to offer the best basis for organizing
discussion groups when this kind of "remote ccntrol" approach is employed.
3. It is not necessary to sacrifice the quality of discussion in order to
achieve quantity. A carefully selected radio program, designed to touch off the
natural well-springs of human interest and concern will lead to discussion as vital
and penetrating as that of a carefully organized graduate seminar.
